results.title: Smokes and Lollies
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Penny Chapman, South Australian Film Corporation and 1:1 Films
results.brief_description: First film in a longitudinal study of three Adelaide girls, aged thirteen and fourteen. They talk about their attitudes to sex and boys, pregnancy, abortion, marriage, school, parenthood and their careers. Their hopes and ambitions pose special questions for adults and young people alike. Edited by David Pulbrook; sound by Rod Pascoe and photographed by Tom Cowan.

results.title: Skidding
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “How to Drive”.
Every driver should aim to drive and control their vehicle so that skidding never occurs. A skid ocurs when any of the three forces acting upon a car in motion - acceleration, braking, steering - is increased sufficiently to overcome the grip of the tyres on the road. Rear wheel, front wheel and four-wheel skids are shown and the right corrective action for each one. Also the types of road surfaces which tend to produce skidding.

results.title: Sister, if you only knew
results.creator_credit: Janet Isaac, Suzanne Baker and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The theme of this film is about the pressures on Aboriginal women living in the city…what effect it has also on their men and their children. The film focuses on four women and the part they played in the movement demanding more equal opportunities for urban Aboriginals, for better conditions, the removal of discriminatory Acts, etc. Although life is difficult the women seem to survive better than the men. Their humour, intelligence and resilience in the face of life’s difficulties often surprise people who see this film. The women are Leila Rankine (Music and Tribal Culture Education), Ruby Hammond (Legail Aid), Mary Williams (Aboriginal Kindergarten) and Gladys Elphick, MBE (President, Aboriginal Women’s Council).

results.title: Sir John Monash
results.creator_credit: Jennie Blackwood, John Martin-Jones, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, State Electricity Commission of Victoria and Zanthus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia today”.
Reviews the life and work of the Australian scholar, lawyer, soldier and engineer, Sir John Monash. Shows his career as an engineer; a commander of troops in World War I; and his work as a Commissioner of the State Electricity Commission during the development of Yallourn. Edited by Jennie Blackwood; photographed by Adrian Bodington; sound by Alan Allen; introduction by John West.

results.title: Ships at work
results.creator_credit: Christopher Cordeaux, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: A small boy finding himself on board a tugboat, learns about the different parts of the ship, and the various functions of other types of ships - dredges, tankers, cargo ships, and a hydrofoil. Explains different loading methods for wheat, wool, coal, oil, and cars. Tells where the goods are from and their destinations.

results.title: Sharing the roads safely
results.creator_credit: Commonwealth Department of Transport, Film Australia and Telemark Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “The Skills of Defensive Driving”.
investigates pedestrians, bicycles, domestic pets, and children as hazards for the driver. Suggests that accident-free driving for all vehicles sharing the road should be the aim for all people.

results.title: Seeing red and feeling blue
results.creator_credit: Jane Oehr, Suzanne Baker and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Provides basic information about reproduction and aspects of menstruation, and probes emotional responses on many aspects of womanhood. The Women’s Theatre Group of Melbourne performs improvisations and satirical sketches which comment on many of society’s prevailing attitudes towards sex education and women.

results.title: Sea road
results.brief_description: Three times a week the “Princess of Tasmania” leaves Melbourne for Devonport. Carrying up to 100 cars and 300 passengers, the ship’s crew deal efficiently and cheerfully with both people and vehicles. We see the passengers and transports loaded, overnight accommodation, and the offloading in the morning.

results.title: Sculpture Australia '69
results.brief_description: Australian sculptors discuss their attitudes towards modern sculpture. Artists shown at work include Norma Redpath creating the fountain for the Commonwealth Treasury, Steven Walker, Ken Reinhart, Robert Klippel, Clement Meadmore and Vincent Jomantis

results.title: School in the mailbox
results.creator_credit: Stanley Hawes and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: By plane, train, buggy, bike, camel and car, school reaches the children of the Australian outback. Correspondence schooling is available for outback children from primary to high school standard, and for many Australians, the school lessons the mailman brings are the only ones they ever receive. Directed by Stanley Hawes, this documentary was produced in a remarkably short time and was sent to Paris as Australia’s contribution to the 1946 UNESCO conference. It was also nominated for an Academy Award for the best documentary short of 1947. Photographed by William Trerise, music by John Antill.
